Executive Summary



The Stationary Source and the Regulated Substances Handled



Substance: Chlorine

Maximum Inventory: 8,000 pounds



The General Accidental Release Prevention Program and the Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps



The facility has developed and implemented a written program to comply with the Accidental Release Prevention requirements codified under 40 CFR Part 68 of the EPA,  and the Process Safety Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals standard codified under 29 CFR Part 1910.119 of the Department of Labor (OSHA).   



The following sections briefly describe the elements of these prevention programs.  



Process Safety Information (PSI)



The facility maintains a detailed record of written process safety information that describes the hazards of the covered process including chemical and process specific information, operating procedures and parameters, engineering controls and safety systems.



Process Hazard Analysis (PHA)



The facility has performed a hazard analysis to validate the procedures and engineering controls in the covered process.  This also included a review of Human Factors and Facility Siting.   All employees have been notified about this analysis and how to obtain the information that is contained within.



Operating Procedures



The facility maintains written operating procedures and an emergency response plan.  The procedures a validated annually to insure appropriateness.



Training



The facility trains it's employees on the Operating Procedures and the Safety System that are incorporated into the process.  It also provides training on the regulations that pertain to this process including specific components like the PHA.  This includes new and existing employees.  





Mechanical Integrity (MI)



A Preventative Maintenance program has been implemented that covers the entire Covered Process.  The program is based on Recognized and Generally Accepted Good Engineering Practices (RAGAGEP) through the use of no

n-consensus documentation and original equipment manufacturers (OEM) maintenance recommendations.      



Management of Change (MOC)



Written procedures are in places at the facility to control changes to process chemicals, technology, equipment and procedures. 



Pre-Startup Reviews



A Pre-startup safety reviews is available to confirm that changes to the Process or the written plan are implemented and managed safely.



Compliance Audits



The facility conducts audits on a regular basis to ensure that the programs that have been developed are being implemented correctly.   These audits are performed at a minimum of at least every three years and

any corrective actions and recommendations are documented.  



Incident Investigation



In the event of an incident, the facility will conduct a prompt investigation as well as document any findings and communicate this information to the appropriate employees and stake-holders.    



Employee Participation



The facility seeks input from all employees and encourages their participation in this process.  



Contractors and Visitors



The facility has a strict policy of informing all contractors and visitors, on a need-to-know- basis, of any potential hazards related to the covered processes.  Their work/visit will always be supervised.









Emergency Response Plan



The facility maintains a written emergency response plan that is a coordinated effort between its employees, outside contractors, chemical suppliers and offsite emergency responders.
